awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: From catalysis to photovoltaics, metal oxide surfaces are commonplace elements of materials design. In catalysis, metal oxides are employed as supports for catalysts. In photovoltaics, they constitute electrode materials. A trend in current research efforts is to find inexpensive modifications to metal oxides so that specific properties of the complex material can be achieved. This goal is particularly important for the catalysis industry, in which the oxide support can be orders of magnitude less expensive than the catalyst. Enabled by state-of-the-art computer simulations and imaging/spectroscopy techniques, this project aims at finding energy-efficient and inexpensive modifications to aluminum oxide that can alter its electronic behavior allowing it to become electron rich. Electron richness is an interesting general property of materials which can be used to boost catalyst performance as well as photovoltaic function. The research is carried out by training university-level students under the supervision of the PI and co-PI, and it is supported by an outreach program involving training high school students in materials modeling and imaging from low-income backgrounds during the summer.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The goal of the project is to devise simple ceramic engineering processes to fabricate electron-rich gamma alumina surfaces. The goal is pursued in tandem by quantum-mechanical calculations based on periodic density functional theory and by materials synthesis, imaging, and spectroscopy. Alumina nanoparticles of different sizes are being doped with phosphorus and nitrogen with the aim of placing the dopant subsurface, sheltered from atmospheric oxygen. On the theory side, high-throughput calculations are analyzing a large number of possible configurations of the alumina surface and dopant location.

por.por_cntn:
Major activities

Our major activity was to complete the investigations on un-doped and P-doped γ-Al2O3. Experimentally, we have finalized the characterization measurements of the already synthesized γ-Al2O3 nanoparticles. In addition to the previous Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of both un-doped and P-doped γ-Al2O3 we get higher resolution SEM images by coating the samples with gold. Also, we completed the final stages of XPS measurements. Theoretically, we have determined work function (WF) values of all un-doped, P-doped and two P-doped surfaces. In order to see the role of hydroxylation on the work function various morphologically different structures of two basis model surfaces, oxygen terminated and 100% hydroxylated surfaces, have been considered using a computational methodology that we developed for computing surface-averaged electrostatic potentials and subsequent surface dipole contributions.     

 

Significant results

We obtained new higher resolution SEM images, for which the samples were coated with gold using ion beam coater (see Figure 1). It is clearly seen that both un-doped and P-doped species have the same morphology showing that P dopant does not have an impact on macroscopic morphology of the material.

 

We also conducted Energy-dispersive X ray Spectroscopy (EDS) measurements, using EDAX coupled with FE-SEM Hitachi S-4800, to see the elemental composition of the specimen in P-doped γ-Al2O3. This allows us to know that the weight% and atomic% of P are 8.50 and 5.78, respectively. 

 

To experimentally determine the work functions of un-doped and P-doped γ-alumina particles, PeakForce Kelvin probe force microscopy (PF-KPFM™) in an Argon-filled glovebox was conducted. For achieving a more conclusive result, PF-KPFM measurement was carried out on several spots in each sample, and particles with similar dimensions were subject to the work function measurements (Figure 2). We found that the average measured work function of the γ-Al2O3 is 4.88±0.04 eV, whereas that of P-doped γ -Al2O3 is 4.16±0.06 eV. This shows that doping of γ -Al2O3 by phosphorus leads a reduction of its work function by almost 15%.

 

Theoretically, to find out the influence of the P doping on the work function and surface dipole in γ -Al2O3 surfaces we have studied an array of possible doping configurations of both single P and two P atoms on the surface and subsurface Al sites.  To construct and analyze these surfaces we used two different sized bulk unit cells. The first cell was a small bulk unit containing 40 atoms with a cell volume of 421 Å3 and a supercell, generating a 160-atom bulk, with a volume of 1684 Å3.

As an example, some of the two P doped local minima surface geometries with the computed PDOS of the second doped P atom for hydroxylated model and that with water removed from the surface are given in Figure 3. Water was removed from the model and re-optimized to see how the surface structure adjusts with water being eliminated.

 

We have carried out work function calculations for several single P-doped and two P-doped structures of oxygen terminated and 100% hydroxylated surface models. Comparison of the results is presented in Figure 4. In these calculations, apart from normal DFT, we also computed the work functions using GGA+U calculations on the structures of 160 atoms. It can be noticed in Figure 4 that the the calculated values of work functions using GGA+U are higher than those using DFT.  Some other significant points obtained from these results are as follows: (i) work functions of oxygen terminated surfaces are much higher (almost two times) compared to hydroxylated surfaces; (ii) In coincidence with experimental results, we have a similar trend for both oxygen terminated and hydroxylated surfaces where the work functions decrease with P doping; and (iii) the values of hydroxylated surfaces are rather comparable with the experimental values. This is expected that the ideal surfaces form with hydroxyls. Furthermore, our calculations for the structures of 40 atoms reveal that both work function and surface dipole values are lower for oxygen terminated surfaces but higher for hydroxylated surfaces than the corresponding surface structures of 160 atoms.
